Directions
In a large pitcher, combine wine with brandy (or rum). Stir in orange and lemon juices.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Add diced orange and apple to pitcher. Twist orange and lemon zests to express oils into pitcher, then add zests to pitcher. Stir to combine, then refrigerate until fully chilled, at least 2 and up to 8 hours (we prefer a roughly 4-hour maceration time; see make-ahead section below).
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Gently stir club soda into pitcher.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Stir in simple syrup, adding more to taste, 1 tablespoon at a time, if desired. If you only added a portion of the brandy (or rum) earlier, you can stir more in now to taste, if desired, then continue to adjust with simple syrup until desired final flavor is reached.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Fill glasses with ice, if desired. Ladle chilled sangria into glasses, garnish with orange wedges, and serve.
Serious Eats / Amanda Suarez
Notes
In our tastings, we preferred the full 1 cup of brandy or rum per 750ml bottle of wine, but if you're unsure, you can start with the lesser 1/2-cup amount, and then mix in more to taste at the end if desired.
To make simple syrup, stir or shake 1/2 cup cold water with 1/2 cup granulated sugar until sugar is fully dissolved. Keep refrigerated until ready to use.
Make-Ahead and Storage
The wine, brandy, and fruit can be left to macerate for up to 8 hours before finishing and serving, though the fruit can over-soften and the sangria can develop bitter flavors if left too long. We found a 4-hour maceration time to strike a good balance between achieving a good infusion of flavor and maintaining bright and fresh flavors and textures.
